Author: wbradt#2043
Content: How do I use `autoprice` to place an order at a price that doesn't change?

Author: SHossain#0007
Content:
```JSON
curl --url "http://127.0.0.1:7783" --data "{\"userpass\":\"$userpass\",\"method\":\"autoprice\",\"base\":\"KMD\",\"rel\":\"BEER\",\"fixed\":0.4}"
curl --url "http://127.0.0.1:7783" --data "{\"userpass\":\"$userpass\",\"method\":\"autoprice\",\"base\":\"BEER\",\"rel\":\"KMD\",\"fixed\":100}"
```

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: if you can't set amount, just keep the amount you want to trade in the barterDEX address and send the rest to main account. in any circumstances, using main account for barterDEX is not recommended. always better to create a separate address for trading.

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: @jl777c I have a question about the alice order types that you mention at https://discordapp.com/channels/412898016371015680/449948412960440352/460433104301981696. I was under the impression that an alice order can result in only one trade. What is the difference between `fill:0` and `fill:1`?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: fill:1 would only ordermatch if it fills the order

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: fill:0 will accept a partial fill

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: Ohhh thank you

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: And, to make sure I understand, IOC orders (`fill:0 gtc:0`) are not _immediate_, but cancel after one minute, or the "typical blocktime"?

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: So the effect is that an IOC order can only match with orders placed before it?

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: And what would be the effect of `gtc` on a `dump` or `fomo` order? Would `fill` work for these?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: gtc would just keep issuing it till it got some sort of fill

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: not sure if i tested fill on a dump or fomo, but i dont see why it would behave differently, their purpose is to autocalculate a price field

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but it could be an edge case bug

Author: Acura#2748
Content: ERC20 Lightning Atomic Swap? https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=1&v=OLlFegcEZ8Y

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: Is there any reason intrinsic to atomic swaps for why the trader using 212% is the liquidity provider?

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content: @wbradt Hi, the swap protocol was designed at 2015-2016 when only few coins implemented BIP65 (CLTV opcode support). This approach allows 1 side of swap to send standard 2of2 multisig payment without timelock. Nowadays it's not really necessary as most coins seem to catch up and implement BIP65. According to this we will use simpler symmetric protocol version (both payments are CLTV) in MM2 so LP side won't need to have 212% balance anymore

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: Thanks! @artem.pikulin very informative

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: The docs say `recentswaps` "returns up to "limit" in reverse order the swaps on the node and the current pending swap (if any) so you can see what trade might happen." Does this mean it returns only swaps in which I have participated?

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: yes

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: @artem.pikulin So in MM2 would both sides of the trade need only 100%? Or does alice still pay dexfee? Or some other arrangement?

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content: @wbradt Alice will have to pay small dexfee = 1/777 of trading amount as it was previously.

Author: wbradt#2043
Content: Thanks--does bob then pay 100%?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i think bob might need to also pay 1/777

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content:
In current implementation Bob does not pay any fee except standard transaction commission. So the protocol is (Bitcoin script example):
1. A fee, p2pkh output: `OP_DUP OP_HASH160 FEE_RMD160 OP_EQUALVERIFY OP_CHECKSIG`
2. B payment: 
```
OP_IF
<now + LOCKTIME*2> OP_CLTV OP_DROP <bob_pubB0> OP_CHECKSIG
 OP_ELSE
OP_SIZE 32 OP_EQUALVERIFY OP_HASH160 <hash(bob_privN)> OP_EQUALVERIFY <alice_pubA0> OP_CHECKSIG
OP_ENDIF
```
3. A payment:
```
OP_IF
<now + LOCKTIME> OP_CLTV OP_DROP <alice_pubA0> OP_CHECKSIG
OP_ELSE
OP_SIZE 32 OP_EQUALVERIFY OP_HASH160 <hash(bob_privN)> OP_EQUALVERIFY <bob_pubB0> OP_CHECKSIG
OP_ENDIF
```
It's actually not hard to add Bfee as work is in progress.

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content:
`Bob does not pay any fee except standard transaction commission.`
So, no deposit anymore? at all?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there would need to be something at stake for bob, so lets add the 1/777 fee to bobside also

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content: Is it really required? There is always a case when someone loses fee if other side does not follow the protocol. Bob side didn't require a fee and it's introduced as liquidity provider advantage

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: are you sure bob cant get an advantage without a dexfee?

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content: @ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢ Yes, no need for Bob deposit anymore.

Content: I'd think that the "need" would be to not be able to screw Alice out of dex fees for the cost of 0.0001 CoinX

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: oh, you mean that whole stage is gone?

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: sweet

Author: artem.pikulin#0794
Content: I mean that Bob did not have to pay fee previously, it's a bonus for being the liquidity provider. It's usual for marketmaker to pay less fees or not pay these at all.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok, but if nobody is putting up liquidity anymore, then without dexfee, it seems bad things can happen

Content: I think bob not paying a transaction fee would be ideal, as it provides the incentive to make liquidity.
